name: Process Engineering Ontology Glossary v1.0.0
description: Comprehensive definitions for all terms in the Process Engineering Ontology

glossaryTerms.name: Process
glossaryTerms.description: A structured sequence of activities, tasks, and decisions designed to achieve specific business outcomes through systematic execution
glossaryTerms.usageExample: The Application Scaffold Process transforms requirements into deployable code through 9 systematic phases
glossaryTerms.usageContext: Use when defining any structured business activity that has inputs, activities, and outputs
glossaryTerms.businessMeaning: A standardized way of accomplishing business objectives that can be repeated, measured, and improved
glossaryTerms.technicalMeaning: A formal specification with defined inputs, outputs, activities, roles, and success criteria
constraints: Must have at least one ProcessPhase
Must define clear business objectives
Must specify success metrics
glossaryTerms.aiAgentUsage: AI agents can orchestrate process execution, optimize phase sequencing, and predict process outcomes

glossaryTerms.name: ProcessPhase
glossaryTerms.description: A distinct stage within a process that groups related activities and produces specific deliverables
glossaryTerms.usageExample: Phase 1: Domain Definition includes analyzing requirements, mapping to schema.org, and creating ontology-config.json
glossaryTerms.usageContext: Use to break down complex processes into manageable, sequential units of work
glossaryTerms.businessMeaning: A checkpoint in the process where specific value is delivered and progress can be measured
glossaryTerms.technicalMeaning: A collection of activities with defined inputs, outputs, entry/exit criteria, and quality gates
constraints: Must belong to exactly one Process
Must have unique sequenceOrder within Process
Cannot depend on phases with higher sequenceOrder (no circular dependencies)
glossaryTerms.aiAgentUsage: AI agents can automate phase activities, validate completeness, and trigger transitions

glossaryTerms.name: ProcessArtifact
glossaryTerms.description: A tangible deliverable or output produced by a process phase that provides value to stakeholders
glossaryTerms.usageExample: TypeScript types, Zod schemas, and JSON schemas generated by the Code Generation phase
glossaryTerms.usageContext: Use to specify what concrete outputs each phase must produce
glossaryTerms.businessMeaning: Evidence that work has been completed and value has been created
glossaryTerms.technicalMeaning: A file, document, configuration, or other tangible output with defined quality criteria
constraints: Must be produced by at least one ProcessPhase
Must have defined quality criteria
Must specify format and storage location
glossaryTerms.aiAgentUsage: AI agents can auto-generate artifacts, validate quality, and manage versioning

glossaryTerms.name: ProcessGate
glossaryTerms.description: A decision point that controls progression between phases by validating completion criteria
glossaryTerms.usageExample: Tests Pass gate validates that unit tests, integration tests, and E2E tests all pass before proceeding to optimization
glossaryTerms.usageContext: Use to ensure quality and completeness before allowing process progression
glossaryTerms.businessMeaning: A quality control mechanism that prevents defects from propagating downstream
glossaryTerms.technicalMeaning: A set of validation rules and approval criteria that must be satisfied
constraints: Must define clear, measurable criteria
Must specify responsible approver role
Must have binary pass/fail outcome
glossaryTerms.aiAgentUsage: AI agents can automate gate evaluation, provide recommendations, and escalate exceptions

glossaryTerms.name: ProcessMetric
glossaryTerms.description: A quantifiable measure that indicates process performance, quality, or business impact
glossaryTerms.usageExample: Time to MVP: Target 14 days from requirements to deployed MVP
glossaryTerms.usageContext: Use to define success criteria and enable continuous process improvement
glossaryTerms.businessMeaning: Evidence of process effectiveness in achieving business objectives
glossaryTerms.technicalMeaning: A measurable variable with target values, units, and calculation methods
constraints: Must have defined target value and unit
Must be objectively measurable
Should align with business objectives
glossaryTerms.aiAgentUsage: AI agents can collect metrics, calculate values, and predict performance trends

glossaryTerms.name: AIAgent
glossaryTerms.description: An artificial intelligence system that augments, automates, or optimizes process activities
glossaryTerms.usageExample: Claude Code CLI agent that generates TypeScript types and database schemas automatically
glossaryTerms.usageContext: Use to specify AI capabilities that enhance process execution
glossaryTerms.businessMeaning: A technology asset that increases process efficiency and reduces manual effort
glossaryTerms.technicalMeaning: A software agent with defined capabilities, autonomy level, and integration points
constraints: Must specify clear capabilities and limitations
Must define autonomy level and human oversight requirements
Should integrate with existing process tools
glossaryTerms.aiAgentUsage: AI agents can coordinate with other AI agents to orchestrate complex multi-agent workflows

glossaryTerms.name: hasPhase
glossaryTerms.description: Links a process to its constituent phases in execution order
glossaryTerms.usageExample: Application Scaffold Process hasPhase Domain Definition, Code Generation, Database Setup
glossaryTerms.usageContext: Use to structure processes into manageable phases
glossaryTerms.businessMeaning: Defines the logical breakdown of work within a process
glossaryTerms.technicalMeaning: A composition relationship with ordered cardinality
constraints: Process must have at least one phase
Phases must maintain logical sequence
glossaryTerms.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this to understand process structure and orchestrate phase execution

glossaryTerms.name: produces
glossaryTerms.description: Links a phase to the artifacts it creates or generates
glossaryTerms.usageExample: Code Generation phase produces TypeScript types, Zod schemas, JSON schemas
glossaryTerms.usageContext: Use to specify expected deliverables from each phase
glossaryTerms.businessMeaning: Defines the value creation points within the process
glossaryTerms.technicalMeaning: A production relationship linking activities to outcomes
constraints: Critical phases should produce at least one artifact
Artifacts must meet defined quality criteria
glossaryTerms.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this to validate completeness and auto-generate required artifacts

usageGuidelines.naming: Use PascalCase for entities, camelCase for properties, kebab-case for IDs
usageGuidelines.extensions: Extend schema.org types when possible, create custom only when necessary
usageGuidelines.versioning: Follow semantic versioning for ontology changes
usageGuidelines.validation: All instances must validate against defined constraints
